metadata.Title: CVE-2019-13050 on Ubuntu 18.04 LTS (bionic) - low
metadata.Description:
Interaction between the sks-keyserver code through 1.2.0 of the SKSkeyserver network, and GnuPG through 2.2.16, makes it risky to have a GnuPGkeyserver configuration line referring to a host on the SKS keyservernetwork. Retrieving data from this network may cause a persistent denial ofservice, because of a Certificate Spamming Attack.

    Update Instructions:

    Run `sudo pro fix CVE-2019-13050` to fix the vulnerability. The problem can be corrected
    by updating your system to the following package versions:

dirmngr - 2.2.4-1ubuntu1.5
gnupg - 2.2.4-1ubuntu1.5
gnupg-agent - 2.2.4-1ubuntu1.5
gnupg-l10n - 2.2.4-1ubuntu1.5
gnupg-utils - 2.2.4-1ubuntu1.5
gnupg2 - 2.2.4-1ubuntu1.5
gpg - 2.2.4-1ubuntu1.5
gpg-agent - 2.2.4-1ubuntu1.5
gpg-wks-client - 2.2.4-1ubuntu1.5
gpg-wks-server - 2.2.4-1ubuntu1.5
gpgconf - 2.2.4-1ubuntu1.5
gpgsm - 2.2.4-1ubuntu1.5
gpgv - 2.2.4-1ubuntu1.5
gpgv-static - 2.2.4-1ubuntu1.5
gpgv-win32 - 2.2.4-1ubuntu1.5
gpgv2 - 2.2.4-1ubuntu1.5
scdaemon - 2.2.4-1ubuntu1.5
No subscription required

criterions.comment: sks: while related to the CVE in some way, a decision has been made to ignore this issue (note: 'end of standard support, was deferred').
gnupg2 package in bionic was vulnerable but has been fixed (note: '2.2.4-1ubuntu1.5').
